Posts.Content: My Mom is 67. She went in for her mammogram last week and there were "calcium deposits" or calcium spots, I can't remember exactly how she said it. They did a repeat mammogram and now they've ordered a biopsy. The doctor said it's because they've changed since her last mammo in late 2009. He also said that it's a "line" of spots and that when it's breast cancer, it's normally in a cluster but he wants to rule out cancer so they're doing a needle biopsy. Is this correct? That bc is normally in a cluster? And I don't know anything about how cancer forms...will they biopsy every spot? What if they biopsy one and it's fine but one that they didn't is cancerous? Is that possible? How does this all work? Sorry for all the questions but I just lost my father in law to C and this has me really scared.
Posts.Title: Calcium deposits in breast? Biopsy being done

Posts.Content: Thank you so much. The biopsy was benign. It's papiloma (sp) and she will probably have surgery to remove it because it's "pre-cancerous"

Thank you very much.
